header.topics: Language, hobbies, family, work, travel, weekend plans
header.activity: Neighbours catching up over a cup of tea.

body.u: yeah cos I still help out with the air cadets as a civilian instructor
oh okay
and I find that eh sometimes it's a little bit easier a little bit difficult to pick up what the youngsters are saying because they have a slightly different lingo
mm
for instance if they say something's cool I expect it to be a bit cold But in fact that's not what they mean
and safe safe means good
oh does it?
yes
oh has an Australian cousin who comes over here and he obviously is irritated by his grandchildren's use of the word cool
right
Yeah and he always says but it's not cool
it's positively boiling
and so what you also study German you said?
I do a German discussion group once a week
okay
to try to keep up the German that I learnt when I was travelling to Germany on business
ah
about thirty years ago thirty or forty years ago
and did you?
which is really work around the motor industry so vocabulary and the usage I learned was tended to be a bit on the technical side
mm hm
although now they say I've got quite a good vocabulary but I've found it rather difficult to string the words together
well German's quite a complicated language
well it is because of the different tenses
mm
but I mean for instance if you say the you could say the man bit the dog or the dog bit the man and it it wouldn't matter which way round you put the words
eh huh
because a German would still be able to pick up from the tense whether
ooh
it was the dog or the man that did the biting
of course cos it has all the different
of course you can't
cases
you can't have that in English
mm
em but eh they say that vocabularies are more important than than grammar
mm hm
not for foreigners come over here and they invariably get the grammar wrong but you still understand what they're talking about
yeah the most important thing is to communicate isn't it? I think
yes it is
vocabulary will help you do that more than grammar and how about Portuguese then?
well Portuguese I found very difficult
mm
I couldn't well I suppose I'm older now and memory doesn't stick quite so well
mm
but I found it extremely difficult and other people have told me that eh it's not an easy language to learn
mm
and so I didn't pursue it I decided that eh
oh no
em too many of them can speak English and they seem to sympathise with the problem and so I get on alright and a lot of the people I mix with over there are English people anyway
mm hm
so eh I get by
mm and it's quite similar to Spanish Portuguese
so I believe yes
I remember it being quite difficult at the beginning to learn Spanish just cos I d it's such a wealth different words that don't have any correspondence to English

but I believe Finnish is one of the mo more difficult ones because I believe there are umpteen different cases in Finnish far more in than other languages it's quite a quite a complex language I believe
oh really? Oof I don't know
but the the other at the the the extreme end of the scale I suppose you've got eh Chinese where
mm
inflections em come into play
yes and all the different characters
yes yes
they the Chinese students that I was working with they said that em they didn't know all their characters of the Chinese language that it's very difficult to be completely
yeah
knowledgeable about it cos they're so many our alphabet is quite limited compared to to to theirs

So what else are you enjoying doing during your retirement?
em well my main hobby I suppose is em model flying
mm hm
I've built some em model aeroplanes radio-controlled model aeroplanes and em I fly those when the weather is good enough eh originally they were all em powered by internal combustion engines

but now electric motors are coming into force and with the improved technology em in battery manufacturers y y y there are more powerful electric motors available and they the batteries will give eh a greater capacity for a given weight

and that's
how big are they?
what? The aeroplanes?
uh-huh
well the the em internal combustion engine sort of something like a five foot wing span
okay
em
gosh it's quite large
yes
not bad
yes
And where do you?
fortunately I'm breaking fewer of them now
yeah
fingers crossed
and do you make do you make them too?
when I first started I bought kits of balsa and plywood
mm hm

and built them from kits but now em it's almost cheaper to buy them built up as almost ready to fly or ARTF em models made in China the Chinese seem to be able to build the complete models so much eh cheaper almost cheaper and you can buy the covering materials for a kit so that eh most of the ones I build now I build from kits
mm hm
or from made up almost ready to fly kits
mm
but you still have to put the tail plane on and the wings and put all the em the electronic the electrical components in it
mm
for instance the radio receiver and the servers and operate the flying services
mm
and the engine
sounds like fun do you have to paint them too?
no no they they're usually covered eh in a sort of plasticky material
uh-huh
and eh y y you should really eh r run a warm covering all over them just to tighten the the skin up but em t they it's reduced a lot of time in constructing them
A where do you go to fly them?
em I belong to two clubs one at eh and em one just north of but the one is threatened by high speed rail
oh what is that?
it's planned to go right across the runway
ooh
that's the new London to Birmingham high speed rail link
that's the yes
and it's planned to go on up to Manchester and Leeds and Scotland in the distant future
mm hm I've heard of that
very controversial
it is
I doubt whether it's viable really I think it's eh a a a bit of a whim that it could eh be financially viable
mm
they built one in Holland and I gather that's not eh eh a financial success
no
and we could end up with another millstone round our necks
I believe so and they I thought it was high speed it would cut si it would cut significantly the time from London to Birmingham but it doesn't
I don't think it does
it's only about twenty-five minutes faster
there's also some university professor has looked at the em eh the effects on the track of a train travelling at
mm
the sort of speeds that they're envisaging and he's come to the conclusion that at that speed vibrations will be set up in the rails and that it could be highly dangerous
oh

so it may well be that em they can't run them as fast as they want to or that they will have to eh strengthen or alter the design of the the the track construction which could put the cost up considerably I don't know
and is it?
I don't know
is it definitely going ahead? They've got the green light?
I think it's envisaged that it will but you never know what opposition groups could drum up to delay it or put it off I don't know
yeah no I saw a lot of eh people who live in a village that's going to be completely razed down
yeah

mm yeah

villages

yes yes

really?
at great expense

it would probably be more viable when it gets eh when it completed and runs right up to Scotland

eh it may then compete with eh with flying

ready to go into the em sausage production machines I suppose but
oh lovely

leather?

and I thought oh what's that? Clicked on it and it was eh something from MacDonald's and I thought

and it's bright pink

well

eh huh
and I think that's mechanically removed meat and it ends up in eh beef burgers and sausages and I'm always a bit suspicious of what
I am completely well this this meat the chicken it was pink because they just put the whole chickens through the grinder so you've got every single part
you've got the bone in there too have you?
yeah everything of the chicken is goes in the grinder and that's why it comes out pink obviously cos it of the blood

like what we know chicken to taste like so it's they might have they might as well just have got a load of polystyrene instead of chicken

no he's not eh but he he he was a Royal Naval helicopter pilot and apart from his other other experiences he had he most a lot of his time was spent with search and rescue at I think he did about six years in all during his service at at Prestwick and em then when he left the Royal Navy he had to requalify as a civilian pilot and eh he got a two year contract with the Irish coastguard em the Irish coastguard are upgrading their helicopters and they wanted other contractors to come in a fly the old ones until the their regular crew were trained up to operate the new ones and then em they would take over again but they've got four search and rescue bases in Ireland and eh they're going to retrain the crews one after the other so he should be working four bases one one after the other and then they've said they'll pay for him to be trained up to operate the new helicopter and the he
does he just pilot helicopters? Or planes as well?

yes oh yes yeah and the Irish say that excuse me if you're you can only be qualified to fly on fly one type of helicopter at a time whereas when he left the Navy he he was em he got qualifications and he was passed to fly about three different types of helicopter he had to get the qualifications and then go to the civil aviation authority at Gatwick and get them to mark up his papers to say he was qualified for each type I think it was the the the em the twin I think it was the em the Single Squirrel and the em em Griffin which is a bell helicopter and then there was the Sea King and em one other I'm not certain what that was
